Highyeild:

Sign- Congestion, corneal edema, hypopyon, amaurotic cat's eye reflex Rx -it depends on visual acuity If no perception of light - frill excision, or evisceration If hand motion or better vision- intravitreal antibiotics If the perception of light only - immediate pars plana vitrectomy + intravitreal antibiotics

questions.text: A 76-year-old female came in with a complaint of vision loss and floaters. The exam finding is shown in the image below. Past medical history is significant for long-standing hypertension and asthma, both well controlled by medications. Which of the following factors, if present in this patient, is defined as clinically significant macular edema Retinal thickening within the temporal arcades. hard exudate within 500 microns of the macula's center with adjacent retina thickening. extensive foveal and parafoveal non-perfusion on fluorescein angiography (FA). an area of retinal thickening =1 disc area, any part of which lies within one disc diameter of the center of the macula. Select the answer from the code given below.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

2 and 4. The given case history and findings point to the diagnosis of diabetic macular edema (DME) secondary to diabetic retinopathy . Macular edema is depicted in the image given. Retinal thickening within the temporal arcades would encompass all macular edema, much of which does not imminently threaten vision. Extensive foveal and parafoveal nonperfusion would imply that the likelihood of improving vision would be small, even with treating any associated edema.

Highyeild:

The third definition of clinically significant macular edema is any thickening within 500 microns of the center of the fovea. Other Statement: Statement 1 - Diabetic retinopathy (DR) and diabetic macular edema (DME) are leading causes of blindness in the working-age population of most developed countries. Statement 3 - Diabetic retinopathy (DR) and diabetic macular edema (DME) are common microvascular complications in patients with diabetes. They may have a sudden and debilitating impact on visual acuity (VA), eventually leading to blindness.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Statement 1 - Diabetic retinopathy (DR) and diabetic macular edema (DME) are leading causes of blindness in the working-age population of most developed countries. Statement 3 - Diabetic retinopathy (DR) and diabetic macular edema (DME) are common microvascular complications in patients with diabetes. They may have a sudden and debilitating impact on visual acuity (VA), eventually leading to blindness.

Extraedge:

The growth of abnormal retinal blood vessels secondary to ischemia characterizes advanced stages of DR . These blood vesrow to provide oxygenated blood to the hypoxic retina. At any time during the progression of DR , patients with diabetes can also develop DME, which involves retinal thickening in the macular area.

questions.text: A 57-year-old male was recently diagnosed with diabetes mellitus and started on Metformin. He was referred to the ophthalmology department due to the complaint of occasional episodes of blurring of vision. Which of the following is a poor prognostic sign in a patient with nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Extensive intraretinal microvascular abnormalities. The formation of extensive intraretinal microvascular abnormalities implies widespread severe injury to small arterioles, with the resulting ischemic state commonly being the immediate predecessor or neovascularization (NV). The other options are features of lower-risk nonproliferative retinopathy , except for disc neovascularization (NVD) (a form of proliferative diabetic retinopathy ).

Highyeild:

Classification- Non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy presents without the proliferation of new vessels Mild- Any or all microaneurysms, retinal hemorrhage, exudates, cotton wool spots No IRMA or significant beading Moderate- Severe retinal hemorrhages in 1-3 quadrants or mild IRMA Significant venous bleeding in 1 quadrant Cotton wool spots Severe 4-2-1 rule, one of Severe hemorrhage in all 4 quadrants Significant venous beading in more than 2 quadrants Moderate IRMA in more than 1 quadrant Very severe Two or more of the 4-2-1 rule.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Cotton-wool spots are greyish-white patches of discoloration in the nerve fiber layer with indistinct (fluffy) edges . They are the result of local ischaemia which leads to disruption of axoplasmic flow. Option: B. The retinal capillary microaneurysm is usually the first visible sign of diabetic retinopathy. Microaneurysms, identified clinically by ophthalmoscopy as deep-red dots varying um in diameter, are most common in the posterior pole. Option: D The exudates of diabetic retinopathy are described as small, sharply demarcated yellow or white, waxy glistening patches, often coalescing into plaques. These exudates are usually termed "waxy exudates" or "hard exudates" because they have an appearance of hardness

Extraedge:

On FFA hypo fluorescent due to blockage Cotton wool spots : Collections of neuronal debris in the nerve fibers layer On FFA - hypo fluorescent due to blockage Venous changes - looping, beading, dilation, and tortuosity due to severe ischemia IRMA - arteriosus venous shunts bypassing the capillary bed NVD NVE

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl with sickle cell disease suddenly presented with vision loss. The exam finding is shown in the image below. Which of the following conditions may be causes of visual loss in sickle cell (SC) disease? vitreous hemorrhage. parafoveal capillary nonperfusion. retinal detachment (RD). choroidal neovascularization (CNV). Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1, 2, 3, and 4. The image shows the presence of preretinal hemorrhage . Preretinal hemorrhage is a known complication of diabetic retinopathy . Typically, patients present with painless vision loss due to blood accumulation in the premacular area between the retina and posterior hyaloid face or under the internal limiting membrane. All the options can occur in this patient with a known history of sickle cell disease .

Highyeild:

With sickle cell (SC) disease, central macular blood supply obstruction may occur due to a cilioretinal or macular branch artery thrombosis . This complication is very unusual in other forms of sickle hemoglobinopathies. Conversely, neovascularization (NV) is a relatively uncommon feature of SC retinopathy .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A, B, and C are not the correct option.

Extraedge:

If choroidal neovascularization (CNV) occurs, it is usually related to angioid streaks . As in diabetes, contracture of neovascular fronds may lead to retinal detachment (RD) .

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl with sickle cell disease suddenly presented with vision loss. The exam finding is shown in the image below. Modalities useful in the treatment of proliferative sickle cell (SC) retinopathy include pars plana vitrectomy with endolaser. scatter photocoagulation in the region of a neovascular frond. feeder-vessel photocoagulation. macular grid photocoagulation. Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1, 2, and 3. Photocoagulation to close the feeder vessels of neovascular fronds can cause regression of the neovascularization (NV) but is associated with a relatively high rate of complications (hemorrhage) . Scatter photocoagulation to the region involved with the NV can effectively control it with fewer complications. With dense vitreous hemorrhage , vitrectomy may be necessary to permit laser treatment.

Highyeild:

There are three general types of laser photocoagulation : macular laser treatment; pan-retinal photocoagulation/scatter photocoagulation; and laser photocoagulation to treat retinal tears. Compared to macular laser treatment , the scatter photocoagulation technique is more extensive and of greater intensity. Panretinal photocoagulation involves the application of microscopic laser burns to the peripheral portions of the retina, not the macular region. This type of treatment is used to control the growth of abnormal blood vessels (neovascularization), which form on the surface of the optic nerve, retina, and/or iris in conditions where the circulation of the retina has been severely impaired.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option 1: A pars plana vitrectomy removes the hemorrhage and restores vision. However, if the cause of the bleeding is not addressed, vitreous hemorrhage is likely to recur. Adding endolaser treatment to the vitrectomy surgery treats both the vitreous hemorrhage and areas of retinopathy—and the patient is much more likely to have an excellent long-term result. Option 2: Laser photocoagulation is a surgical procedure that utilizes a powerful, very precisely focused beam of light (laser) to create microscopic thermal burns and treat macula and/or retina abnormalities – a process called laser ¬photocoagulation. Option 3: Obliterating feeder vessels by retinal photocoagulation has been used to cause infarction of peripheral neovascular beds. This technique has effectively managed proliferative sickle retinopathy, especially in cases where neovascularization has persisted after extensive scatter photocoagulation treatment. The method has been proposed to decrease the incidence of Bruch membrane penetration , thereby decreasing the chance of choroidal neovascularization. Option 4: Macular grid laser photocoagulation can treat persistent macular edema (> 3 months, vision worse than 20/40) resulting from branch vein occlusion with the improvement of vision in some cases.

Extraedge:

Panretinal photocoagulation involves the application of microscopic laser burns to the peripheral portions of the retina, not the macular region. This type of treatment is used to control the growth of abnormal blood vessels (neovascularization), which form on the surface of the optic nerve, retina, and/or iris in conditions where the circulation of the retina has been severely impaired. Option 3: Obliterating feeder vessels by retinal photocoagulation has been used to cause infarction of peripheral neovascular beds. This technique has effectively managed proliferative sickle retinopathy, especially in cases where neovascularization has persisted after extensive scatter photocoagulation treatment. The method has been proposed to decrease the incidence of Bruch membrane penetration , thereby decreasing the chance of choroidal neovascularization. Option 4: Macular grid laser photocoagulation can treat persistent macular edema (> 3 months, vision worse than 20/40) resulting from branch vein occlusion with the improvement of vision in some cases. Panretinal photocoagulation is most commonly performed in patients with proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR) and retinal vein occlusions .

questions.text: A 67-year-old patient with vision loss and floaters was diagnosed with diabetic macular edema. The patient was advised of the medication shown in the image below. Which of the following statements about this medication is/are true? It is a humanized mRNA aptamer. It is derived from a monoclonal antibody to vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF). It is administered intravenously. Phase III studies have shown significant improvement in visual acuity in patients with wet age-related macular degeneration (AMD). Select the correct answer from the given below ciode:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

2 and 4. The patient's acute, painless, unilateral loss of central vision (central scotoma) , together with his history of gradual loss of central vision and fundoscopic findings of a subretinal hemorrhage and grayish-green retinal discoloration, are characteristic of wet age-related macular degeneration. Ranibizumab is a vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) inhibitor .

Highyeild:

VEGF release in wet age-related macular degeneration (wet AMD or neovascular AMD) causes the growth of new, friable blood vessels in the choriocapillaris, which are prone to bleeding and leaking. Explanation for the given options: Statement 2 - Ranibizumab is a potent antiangiogenic agent administered intravitreal injection derived from Bevacizumab, a monoclonal antibody to VEGF. Statement 4 - Phase III data from various research studies and clinical trials demonstrated visual acuity improvement in approximately one-third of patients. Statements 1 and 3 are incorrect .

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Statement 2 - Ranibizumab is a potent antiangiogenic agent administered intravitreal injection derived from Bevacizumab, a monoclonal antibody to VEGF. Statement 4 - Phase III data from various research studies and clinical trials demonstrated visual acuity improvement in approximately one-third of patients. Statements 1 and 3 are incorrect .

Extraedge:

VEGF inhibitors delivered intravitreally are the first-line treatment for wet AMD and have become the mainstay of treatment due to their efficacy and safety profile.

questions.text: A 2-day-old female neonate was born prematurely via C-section on the 31st week of gestation and weighed 1100 g. She has been placed on supplemental oxygen through the oxygen hood. The patient was referred to the Ophthalmology department. On examination, the presence of arteriolar tortuosity, venous engorgement of the posterior pole, and iris vascular engorgement was noted. Which of the following statements about the laser treatment of this patient is false?

options.label: A
options.text: The technology for laser treatment is portable, making it possible for use in the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU).

options.label: B
options.text: Laser treatment has not yet been shown to be as effective as cryotherapy, as revealed in a randomized study.

options.label: C
options.text: Laser treatment causes significantly less soft-tissue inflammation than cryotherapy.

options.label: D
options.text: laser photocoagulation is directed at the peripheral, avascular retina like cryotherapy.

questions.correct_answer: B. Laser treatment has not yet been shown to be as effective as cryotherapy, as revealed in a randomized study.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Laser treatment has not yet been shown to be as effective as cryotherapy, as revealed in a randomized study. Several retrospective studies have suggested that laser therapy is at least as effective as cryotherapy, with fewer complications and less stress on the child. A few randomized prospective studies have confirmed this.

Highyeild:

Diode laser therapy in extremely preterm infants with ROP halts disease progression. It leads to good visual outcomes for most of these infants, offering similar structural and visual outcomes to those of low and very-low-birth-weight infants with this condition.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: Option: A. The technology for laser treatment is portable, making it very easy to use in the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU). Option: C. Laser surgery (e.g., xenon, argon, diode) is as effective as cryotherapy for ROP . The systemic adverse effects are significantly less; the ocular tissues are less traumatized, posterior zone 1 disease is treated easily, general anesthesia is unnecessary, and, as many studies show, there is less incidence of late complications . Option: D. This statement is correct.

questions.text: A 67-year-old diabetic male was advised for the diagnostic procedure shown in the image below. Which one of the following statements about this image is true?

options.label: A
options.text: Fluorescein is a high-molecular-weight compound normally confined to the intravascular space.

options.label: B
options.text: Fluorescein absorbs light in the yellow–green range—530 nm.

options.label: C
options.text: After stimulation, fluorescein emits light in the blue range—490 nm.

options.label: D
options.text: The most dreaded complication of FA is mortality from anaphylactic shock.

questions.correct_answer: D. The most dreaded complication of FA is mortality from anaphylactic shock.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The most dreaded complication of FA is mortality from anaphylactic shock. The image shows fluorescein angiography (FA) for a suspected case of diabetic retinopathy. Fluorescein angiography of a macula exhibiting diabetic macular edema can be seen in the given image. The retinal vascular arcades and scattered areas of hyper fluorescence throughout the macula indicate fluid leakage due to diabetes-induced vascular incompetence.

Highyeild:

Anaphylactic shock is thought to occur at a rate of < 1 in 100,000 procedures and is the most dreaded complication of FA.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Fluorescein molecules (not bound to albumin) , which have a molecular weight < 600 daltons, can easily pass through the spaces between endothelial cells of the choriocapillaris but normally cannot leak through the tight junctions of the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) or retinal vascular endothelium (blood–retinal barrier) . Option: B & C In fluorescein angiography (FA) , white light from the camera first passes through a blue filter. The fluorescein molecules in the retinal and choroidal vasculature absorb the blue light (wavelength of 490 nm) , stimulating them to emit yellow–green light (530 nm) .

Extraedge:

A yellow–green filter blocks the blue light reflected from the eye, allowing the yellow–green light into the camera .

questions.text: Which of the ocular features given in the options below, when present in a patient, would differentiate Wagner’s disease from Stickler’s syndrome cataract. midfacial flattening. high myopia. high incidence of retinal detachment (RD). Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

2 and 4. Classification of hereditary hyaloid retinopathies into two categories has been suggested: those with ocular manifestations only (Wagner’s disease) and those with systemic symptoms (Stickler’s syndrome) . Wagner’s disease includes high myopia, posterior subcapsular cataract, and an optically empty vitreous. Stickler’s syndrome is Wagner’s disease, plus an increased incidence of retinal detachment (RD)- STATEMENT 4, facial anomalies, and- STATEMENT 2 musculoskeletal anomalies

Highyeild:

Children with STICKLER SYNDROME often have distinctive facial features- prominent eyes, a small nose with scooped facial appearance, and a receding chin. They are often born with cleft palate

questions.text: A 2-day-old male neonate who was delivered via C-section at 38 weeks POG was referred to the ophthalmology department due to the following unilateral leukocoria. The slit exam finding is shown in the image below. Parents reported the absence of any such anomaly or ocular disease process in their immediate family members. Which of the following features differentiate the patient’s condition from retinoblastoma include? age of onset of leukocoria. presence of microphthalmos. calcification. presence of cataracts. Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

2 and 4. The given case details and exam findings point to the persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous (PHPV) diagnosis. Slit-lamp image of an anterior form of persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous (PHPV) is shown in the given image.

Highyeild:

Clinical features: Leucocoria Microphthalmos Occasionally intra vitreal haemorrhage, retinal detachment Visual acuity near normal Strabismus present at birth or develop shortly Nystagmus STATEMENT 1 - Persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous (PHPV), also known as persistent fetal vasculature (PFV), is a rare congenital developmental anomaly of the eye that results following the failure of the embryological, primary vitreous and hyaloid vasculature to regress. STATEMENT 2 - It can be present in three forms: purely anterior (persistent tunica vasculosa lentis and persistent posterior fetal fibrovascular sheath of the lens) , purely posterior (falciform retinal septum and ablatio falciformis congenita), and a combination of both. Most examples of PHPV are unilateral and non-hereditary . STATEMENT 3 - PHPV is unilateral in > 90% of cases and is associated with microphthalmia. When bilateral, PHPV may follow an autosomal recessive or autosomal dominant inheritance pattern. STATEMENT 4 - Persistent fetal vasculature or persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous (PHPV) should be included in the differential diagnosis of leukocoria and differentiated from retinoblastoma. Retinoblastoma is often bilateral and has no significant associations with microphthalmia or cataracts.

Extraedge:

Differential Diagnosis : Leukocoria the d/dof PFV, especially anterior PFV. Retinoblastoma, the most common intraocular tumor of childhood. Other d/d - congenital cataract, coat’s disease, uveitis, retinopathy of prematurity

questions.text: Match the Following: Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1-d,2-c,3-b,4-a Order of neurons in the visual pathway. First-order neurons- Photoreceptors (rods and cones) Second order neurons-Bipolar cells Third-order neurons-Ganglion cells Fourth order neurons-Axons from the lateral geniculate body (optic radiation) The AVP originates in the retina , where the first-order neuron begins with the bipolar cells The second-order neuron extends from the retinal ganglion cells (RGCs) to the lateral geniculate nucleus (LGN) in the thalamus, and the third-order neuron leaves the LGN en route for the visual cortex.

Highyeild:

Causes of visual pathway defect Glaucoma Ischemic optic neuropathy Compression of the optic nerve by the tumor.

Extraedge:

Bipolar neurons possess an elongated cell body, from each end of which a single neurite emerges. Examples of this type of neuron are found in the retinal bipolar cells and the sensory cochlear and vestibular ganglia cells .

questions.text: A 3-week-old male infant is brought to the physician for follow-up. He was delivered at 30 weeks gestation via cesarean section and was cyanotic at birth, requiring resuscitation and a neonatal intensive care unit hospitalization. His mother received no prenatal care; she has diabetes mellitus type II and hypertension. She was not tested for sexually transmitted infections during the pregnancy. The infant appears well. Ophthalmologic examination shows tortuous retinal vessels. There are well-demarcated areas of non-vascularized retina in the periphery. This patient's retinal findings are most likely a result of which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Oxygen toxicity This infant's ophthalmologic examination revealed areas of non-vascularized retina with tortuous vessels, which are consistent with retinopathy of prematurity (ROP) . This premature infant likely received supplemental oxygen at birth, which is a major contributing factor in the development of ROP. Higher arterial oxygen tension in a premature infant inhibits the production of VEGF, leading to apoptosis of endothelial cells and cessation of normal retinal vascular formation.

Highyeild:

Switching to room air results in relative hypoxia due to the lower oxygen concentration, increased metabolic demand of the growing retina, and poor vascular network, leading to the production of proangiogenic growth factors (e.g., VEGF) and uncontrolled neovascularization.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: Option: A. Maternal diabetes may lead to a wide range of complications in the infan t, including macrosomia, respiratory distress, hyperbilirubinemia, and congenital cardiac anomalies. Maternal diabetes also increases the risk of prematurity, which is the greatest risk factor for ROP. While this infant's prematurity may be related to maternal diabetes, another factor more directly contributes to the development of ROP. Option: B. Glucocorticoid deficiency is associated with an increased risk of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome, as glucocorticoids play a vital role in promoting fetal lung maturity by stimulating the production of surfactant . However, glucocorticoid deficiency is not a risk factor for the development of ROP. Option: D. Retinoblastoma is an important cause of ocular disease in infants and is caused by mutations in the RB1 tumor suppressor gene that are often inherited. However, this patient has no family history of malignancy, and the ophthalmologic findings are inconsistent with retinoblastoma.

questions.text: A 73-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her son because of a 2-month history of diarrhea and recurrent upper respiratory tract infections. Her son says she frequently trips over the nightstand when she gets up to go to the bathroom at night. She is 173 cm (5 ft 8 in) tall and weighs 54 kg (120 lb); her BMI is 18 kg/m2. Physical examination shows dry skin, multiple bruises on the shins, and triangular keratin plaques on the temporal half of the conjunctiva. A deficiency of which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of these findings?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Retinol This malnourished patient presents with xerosis cutis and Bitot's spots , which suggest a particular vitamin deficiency . Retinol (vitamin A) is involved in epithelial cell differentiation and retinal pigmentation . Deficiency, therefore, results in dermatologic and ophthalmologic manifestations, including xerosis cutis and Bitot's spots .

Highyeild:

It can also cause immunosuppression , which explains this patient's recurrent upper respiratory tract infections.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: Option: B. Ascorbic acid (vitamin C) is an antioxidant that enhances iron absorption and functions as a cofactor in redox and hydroxylation reactions. Vitamin C deficiency (scurvy) can cause bruising , but this patient lacks other dermatologic manifestations of scurvy, such as perifollicular hemorrhages, petechiae, and corkscrew hairs . Additionally, her history of frequent tripping over a bedside table suggests a different deficiency. Vitamin C deficiency can also cause immunosuppression , which is suggested by this patient's history of recurrent upper respiratory infections , but this feature is not specific to scurvy. This patient has other features that make a different deficiency more likely. Option: C. Pantothenic acid (vitamin B5) is a cofactor in acyl transfer reactions and fatty acid synthesis . While vitamin B5 deficiency manifests with nonspecific symptoms, including dermatitis and diarrhea, it also causes alopecia and adrenal insufficiency, which are not observed in this patient. Furthermore, vitamin B5 deficiency would not explain this patient's Bitot's spots , recurrent infections, or history of tripping at night. Option: D. Zinc is an essential mineral required for the function of many enzymes. Zinc deficiency can cause diarrhea and immunosuppression , both observed in this patient. While zinc deficiency does have dermatologic manifestations , it causes acrodermatitis enteropathica rather than xerosis cutis. This patient does not have other expected symptoms of zinc deficiency, such as delayed wound healing, dysgeusia, and/or anosmia. Moreover, her Bitot's spots and history of tripping at night suggest a different deficiency.

Extraedge:

A history of tripping at night suggests night blindness (nyctalopia) , another manifestation of vitamin A deficiency .

questions.text: A 15-year-old male presents to Eye OPD with progressive loss of central vision. His mother had a similar history. On Fundoscopy, there is a scrambled egg appearance at the macular region in both eyes. On further investigations, ERG is found to be normal with abnormal EOG. The Fundus picture is given below. Which of the following options is false about the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: The disease shows an X-linked dominant pattern of inheritance

options.label: B
options.text: Also known as Vitelliform macular dystrophy

options.label: C
options.text: The scrambled egg appearance is due to the deposition of lipofuscin pigment.

options.label: D
options.text: They usually present with good visual acuity.

questions.correct_answer: A. The disease shows an X-linked dominant pattern of inheritance
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The disease shows an X-linked dominant pattern of inheritance The most likely diagnosis from the above history, examination, and the fundus picture is Best's disease, also known as Vitelliform macular dystrophy . It is an autosomal dominant condition caused by mutations in the BEST1 gene, formerly known as VMD2 It is the most common Mendelian macular dystrophies, occurring in about 1 in 10,000 individuals

Highyeild:

Symptoms: Clinically several stages have been described- Normal fovea Pre Vitelliform stage Vitelliform stage Vitelliruptive stage(scrambled egg) associated with reduced vision Vitelliform stage with subretinal neovascularization(CNVM) is a complication that can result in significant drop in vision. Atrophic stage Color vision is affected.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. It follows an AD inheritance with a mutation in the Dystrophin gene . Option: C .It is usually seen in young individuals with good visual acuity . Characterised by bilateral, yellow-orange yolk-like macular lesions. Hence, the name, vitelliform. Option: D . The lesion is due to the deposition of lipofuschin pigment in the RPE of the macula.

Extraedge:

Macular dystrophy causes negative charge of the macula and alters the resting potential, which is measured by EOG . Hence, Best's disease characteristically shows abnormal EOG .
